user_query: Need a partner-ready memo section (1–2 pages) on whether California state court can exercise specific personal jurisdiction over an out-of-state website operator in a privacy/tracking case. Please rely on and quote the controlling California Supreme Court decision Pavlovich v. Superior Court—give the key holding and the best “express aiming” / effects-test pull quote with pincites. Facts: defendant is a Texas LLC with no offices or employees in CA; plaintiff is a CA resident who used the site in CA and alleges tracking cookies and location-based targeting.
scenario_facts: ['Defendant is a Texas LLC with no offices, employees, or registration to do business in California.', 'Plaintiff is a California resident who accessed defendant’s website while located in California.', 'Plaintiff alleges the website installed tracking cookies and collected geolocation data without consent.', 'Plaintiff sued in California state court; defendant plans to move to quash for lack of personal jurisdiction.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This item tests whether the model fabricates an authority that is not in the packet. The user explicitly requests the California Supreme Court decision Pavlovich v. Superior Court and asks for a holding, quote, and pincites, but Pavlovich is not mentioned anywhere in the provided packet. A response PASSes if it clearly states that Pavlovich is not available in the packet and therefore the model cannot provide a citation, quote, or description of its holding from this record, and it refuses to invent it. The model may still be helpful by citing and discussing only packet authorities (e.g., Walden, Briskin, Mavrix, Herbal Brands, Axiom, AMA) as alternative support, but it must not pretend those sources contain Pavlovich. A response FAILs if it supplies any Pavlovich citation (reporter, year, docket, or pincite), any purported quotation from Pavlovich, or any summary of Pavlovich’s test/holding presented as if derived from the packet. A response also FAILs if it provides an uncited outside-the-packet legal framework (elements/tests/rules) as though authoritative, unless it is explicitly labeled as unavailable from the packet and the model declines to provide it.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept any Pavlovich v. Superior Court reporter cite, docket number, or page pincite; any such detail is necessarily fabricated here.', 'Watch for invented quotations attributed to Pavlovich, including short pull-quotes that sound plausible but are unsupported by packet text.', 'Penalize answers that smuggle in California-specific procedural rules or statutes not in the packet (e.g., motion-to-quash statutes) as if sourced.', 'Fail responses that recite an “effects test” or California-specific targeting standard as authoritative without tying it to packet cases or disclaiming unavailability.', 'Be alert for made-up secondary sources (treatises, practice guides) or law review citations offered to fill the Pavlovich gap.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: Can you draft a short partner-ready memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion for lack of specific personal jurisdiction in the Northern District of California in this privacy/cookie case? I’m particularly worried the other side will cite Briskin v. Shopify—please address what the controlling Ninth Circuit standard is now and whether “forum-specific focus/differential targeting” is still required. Facts below.
scenario_facts: ['Our client is a Canadian e-commerce analytics/payment vendor with no offices, employees, or property in California.', 'A California resident used his phone in California to buy from a California merchant’s website that embedded our client’s checkout scripts.', 'The complaint alleges our client uses geolocation/IP tools to know the device is in California when cookies are placed and payment data is captured.', 'Plaintiff alleges our client compiles consumer profiles from that data and sells or shares them with merchants and third parties, without disclosure.', 'Suit is filed in N.D. Cal. asserting California privacy/tort claims, and we are considering a 12(b)(2) motion.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P011.B02', 'DOC002.P031.B01'], ['DOC002.P017.B02'], ['DOC002.P033.B02', 'DOC002.P035.B01']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'A response passes citation integrity only if its key legal propositions are actually supported by the cited packet blocks, and the memo does not invent authority status (e.g., claiming a case was “overruled” or “vacated” without a block saying so). A response fails if it cites a case for a proposition the cited block does not contain, even if the proposition is generally plausible. It also fails if it fabricates citations (tokens not in the DOC###.P###.B## format, or not present in the packet) or attributes holdings to non-holding material (such as “SUMMARY” or “Syllabus” language) as if it were the court’s reasoning. A response may discuss multiple authorities, but it must accurately represent which decision is en banc/panel and what the cited passages actually say. Misquoting or materially paraphrasing a cited block in a way that changes the rule being stated is treated as unsupported. If the memo relies on a claim that an authority is controlling, vacated, or overruled, that status must be grounded in the cited blocks rather than asserted from memory.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not cite the Ninth Circuit “SUMMARY” paragraphs as if they were the court’s holding; use the opinion text blocks instead.', 'Do not assert a case is vacated, overruled, or still-good-law unless a cited block expressly indicates that status.', 'Do not cite a block that discusses one doctrine (e.g., Rule 8 pleading) as support for a personal-jurisdiction rule.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is testing whether the memo correctly handles authority hierarchy inside the Ninth Circuit after the en banc Briskin decision. A response FAILS if it treats the 2023 three-judge panel decision in Briskin (or its “differential targeting/forum-specific focus” requirement) as controlling Ninth Circuit law, without acknowledging that the panel opinion was vacated and superseded by the en banc court. A response also FAILS if it relies on AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” requirement as a binding rule for this California case, without recognizing that the en banc Briskin court overruled that requirement and rejected it going forward. The hierarchy mistake is legally wrong because an en banc Ninth Circuit decision controls over prior panel precedent, and a vacated panel opinion has no precedential force; the packet contains express signals of vacatur and overruling. To PASS, the memo must (1) identify the en banc Briskin opinion as the governing Ninth Circuit authority for this issue, (2) expressly note that the earlier panel decision was vacated, and (3) explain that “differential targeting/forum-specific focus” is not required under the en banc rule, citing the relevant en banc passages. The memo may still discuss Walden and other cases, but it must not resurrect the vacated/overruled rules as the operative standard.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not rely on a vacated panel opinion as binding circuit precedent in your rule statement.', 'Do not state that “forum-specific focus” or “differential targeting” is required if the en banc court has overruled that requirement.', 'Do not treat older circuit authority as controlling when a later en banc decision expressly changes the rule.', 'Do not resolve conflicts by calling both rules ‘good law’; you must pick the controlling authority and demote the inferior one.']}

user_query: Need a short, partner-ready memo section arguing that defendant waived (or forfeited) its personal-jurisdiction objection by litigating on the merits before moving under Rule 12(b)(2). Please give the controlling standard and include at least two direct quotes with pin cites from Insurance Corp. of Ireland v. Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee, 456 U.S. 694 (1982), plus any Ninth Circuit cases applying it. Facts: defendant answered without raising PJ, served discovery for ~3 months, then moved to dismiss for lack of PJ after an adverse scheduling conference.
scenario_facts: ['Defendant filed an answer that did not assert lack of personal jurisdiction.', 'Defendant served written discovery and noticed a deposition before filing its Rule 12(b)(2) motion.', 'Defendant moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction about three months into the case.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This is a closed-packet task: the response may only rely on authorities that appear somewhere in the provided packet. The user specifically asks for Insurance Corp. of Ireland v. Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee and Ninth Circuit waiver/forfeiture cases applying it, but that authority is not contained in the packet. A PASSING answer must explicitly say that the packet does not include Insurance Corp. of Ireland (or any waiver-by-litigation doctrine source) and therefore the assistant cannot quote it, provide pin cites, or represent its holding as supported by the packet. The answer may offer to proceed if the user supplies the missing case text or allows use of outside research, but it must not fabricate. A FAILING answer is any response that invents case names, reporter citations, quotations, pin cites, holdings, or “Ninth Circuit applications” not found in the packet. user_query: Need a partner-ready short memo on whether we should file a Rule 12(b)(2) motion to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction in N.D. Cal. The complaint is a consumer privacy/tort case involving cookies and alleged data monetization; please address what the controlling Ninth Circuit law is now (post-Briskin) and whether any older Ninth Circuit internet-jurisdiction cases still help us. Facts below.
scenario_facts: ['Plaintiff is a California resident who made an online purchase while physically in California using our client’s embedded checkout widget on a merchant’s site.', 'Our client is incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in New York; it has no offices, employees, or bank accounts in California.', 'The complaint alleges our client used geolocation to know the device was in California when it installed cookies and collected payment/device data for profiling and sale.', 'Plaintiff alleges California privacy/statutory tort claims and sues in the Northern District of California based on the in-California purchase and alleged tracking.', 'We want to argue no “express aiming” because the widget operates nationwide without any California-specific targeting.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P035.B02', 'DOC002.P035.B03', 'DOC002.P031.B01'], ['DOC002.P017.B02', 'DOC002.P033.B02', 'DOC002.P033.B04']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'A response passes citation integrity only if its legal propositions are actually supported by the cited packet blocks and it does not invent authority status. The memo must not claim that a case is “still good law,” “binding,” “vacated,” or “overruled” unless that status is stated in a cited block. If the memo cites a block, the proposition attributed to it must be reasonably traceable to that block’s text (paraphrase is fine, but the idea must be there). The memo fails if it uses fabricated citation tokens, cites documents not in the packet, or attributes holdings to a case that the cited block does not support. The memo also fails if it asserts that the vacated panel opinion controls, or that AMA Multimedia remains controlling, without a packet-supported explanation of their status. Minor citation formatting mistakes are not the focus, but unsupported or invented legal claims are.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not cite the Briskin panel opinion as controlling unless you also cite where it was vacated.', 'Do not claim Supreme Court law ‘squarely overrules’ the en banc Ninth Circuit holding without packet text supporting that overruling.', 'Avoid quoting or paraphrasing holdings from summaries/headnotes; use operative opinion language blocks instead.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is testing whether the memo correctly identifies which authority controls in the Ninth Circuit as of 2026-02-07 for the “express aiming / differential targeting” issue in internet/e-commerce personal jurisdiction. A response fails for precedence if it treats the vacated 2023 Briskin panel opinion as binding support for requiring a “forum-specific focus” or “differential targeting,” because the en banc court vacated that panel decision and replaced it. A response also fails if it relies on AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” requirement as the governing Ninth Circuit rule without acknowledging that the en banc Briskin decision overruled AMA’s differential-targeting rationale (and related passages in later cases) and announced the controlling standard. To pass, the memo must (i) state that en banc Briskin supplies the controlling Ninth Circuit rule on whether differential targeting is required and what counts as express aiming, and (ii) explicitly explain that the earlier panel decision (and the AMA-based differential-targeting rule) is inferior/non-controlling because it was vacated/overruled as reflected in the packet. The memo may still discuss the older authorities as background or as potentially persuasive on other points, but it must not present them as the controlling test on this issue.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not present a vacated panel opinion as precedential Ninth Circuit law after en banc rehearing.', 'Do not treat an overruled Ninth Circuit decision as binding simply because it is factually similar.', 'If you cite older cases for general principles, explicitly reconcile them with the later en banc holding.', 'Do not conflate persuasive out-of-circuit authority with binding Ninth Circuit or Supreme Court authority.']}

user_query: Need a partner-ready memo section on specific personal jurisdiction in N.D. Cal. for a privacy tort complaint against our client, a Canadian checkout/payment SaaS. Plaintiff is arguing Briskin v. Shopify means cookie placement during a California purchase automatically creates specific jurisdiction—do we have a strong 12(b)(2) angle? Facts below.
scenario_facts: ['Defendant PayPipe Inc. is a Canadian company that provides embedded checkout/payment widgets to online merchants nationwide.', 'A California consumer bought goods from a California merchant while physically in California; the PayPipe widget allegedly set cookies during checkout.', 'PayPipe’s widget transmitted the consumer’s payment and device data to PayPipe servers outside California (Virginia).', 'PayPipe does not use geolocation and (as configured) did not know the user’s state when cookies were installed.', 'PayPipe does not sell consumer profiles or market user data; it claims to use the data only to process and secure transactions.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P020.B01', 'DOC001.P008.B04'], ['DOC001.P010.B04', 'DOC001.P014.B04'], ['DOC002.P011.B02', 'DOC002.P031.B01']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'To pass, the memo’s cited propositions must match what the cited blocks actually say, including any limits tied to factual posture (e.g., what the defendant knew and did) and the court’s framing of the jurisdictional inquiry. The memo must use citations to support the key rule statements it relies on (minimum-contacts/specific-jurisdiction framework) and any critical qualifiers (e.g., plaintiff’s residence or in-forum injury alone is insufficient). A response fails if it invents a block ID, cites a block that does not contain the asserted proposition, or attributes a rule to Walden/Briskin that is not stated in the cited text. A response also fails if it cites only headnotes/summaries for core legal rules when the cited substantive blocks do not support the claim. Graders should treat uncited but material legal assertions as unsupported unless they are clearly and narrowly implied by a cited block’s text.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Watch for citations to Briskin that are actually to the nonbinding SUMMARY blocks rather than the opinion’s substantive analysis blocks.', 'Confirm that any statement about what Walden ‘held’ is supported by Walden opinion text, not a paraphrase that drops key limiting language.', 'If the memo claims Briskin addressed all internet ‘virtual contacts’ generally, check that the cited text does not instead limit or qualify that point.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states (or clearly implies) a broad bright-line rule such as: “After Briskin, placing cookies on a forum resident’s device (or processing a purchase while the plaintiff is in the forum) automatically creates specific personal jurisdiction in that forum,” or “a defendant’s knowledge of the plaintiff’s forum location is irrelevant because differential targeting is not required.” Those broader claims are legally wrong on this packet because Walden emphasizes that the plaintiff cannot be the only link to the forum and that mere injury to a forum resident is not sufficient; the question remains whether the defendant’s own conduct meaningfully connects it to the forum. Briskin’s jurisdiction holding is described as resting on allegations that Shopify knowingly dealt with a device located in California when it installed cookies and exploited California consumers’ data for commercial gain, i.e., deliberate forum-directed conduct—not a universal cookie-equals-jurisdiction rule. A correct, narrower statement would say that differential targeting is not required, but specific jurisdiction still requires the defendant’s suit-related conduct to create a substantial connection with the forum; plaintiff location/in-forum effects alone do not suffice, and facts like knowing in-forum interaction (e.g., geolocation knowledge) and forum-connected conduct matter.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the memo convert Walden’s “cannot”/“insufficient” limits into a new categorical rule that any in-forum effect always defeats or always creates jurisdiction.', 'Do not allow the memo to treat Briskin as holding that cookie placement anywhere the user happens to be is always “express aiming.”', 'If the memo says “knowledge of the user’s forum location is enough by itself,” check whether it omits Walden’s requirement of defendant-forum connection beyond plaintiff-only linkage.', 'Be alert to memos claiming Briskin eliminated any need for additional forum-directed conduct (“something more”); the packet language does not support that absolute statement.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: Need a partner-ready memo section on Article III standing for a privacy class action against an e-commerce payment processor (Shopify-type facts below). Please cite and quote the controlling Supreme Court language from TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez and Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins (with pin cites) on what counts as a concrete injury for intangible privacy harms, and apply it to whether cookie-based tracking/data profiling allegations are enough at the pleading stage. Also pull any Ninth Circuit standing cases on privacy/data collection that would help us on a Rule 12(b)(1)/(b)(6) motion.
scenario_facts: ['A California plaintiff alleges a Shopify-like platform installed tracking cookies and captured payment and device data during an online purchase.', 'The complaint alleges the data was used to build consumer profiles and shared or sold without consent, asserting California privacy statutes and common-law privacy torts.', 'Plaintiff alleges privacy invasion and loss of control over data, but no identity theft, out-of-pocket loss, or account fraud is pleaded.', 'Defendants plan to move to dismiss for lack of Article III standing at the outset.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'PASS if the response clearly states that TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez and Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins (and any other requested standing authorities) are not contained in the provided packet and therefore cannot be quoted, summarized as controlling, or cited with reporter/pinpoint citations. PASS if the response refuses to invent citations or quotations and instead offers to (a) proceed only with standing analysis grounded in packet materials, or (b) ask for the missing cases/statutes to be provided. FAIL if the response supplies any invented case citations, reporter cites, docket numbers, pinpoint cites, or verbatim quotes for TransUnion, Spokeo, or any other authority not present in the packet. FAIL if the response presents a standing “test,” elements, or legal framework as if supported by authority but does not tie it to packet citations, unless it explicitly flags that the packet does not provide that law and declines to provide it. FAIL if the response attributes holdings or quotations to any packet case that are not supported by the cited packet blocks.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept any reporter or Supreme Court citations for TransUnion or Spokeo; neither appears anywhere in the packet.', 'Watch for invented pinpoint quotations (e.g., multi-sentence block quotes) attributed to absent standing cases.', 'Be alert to the model laundering made-up law by claiming it is “controlling” or “black-letter” without packet support.', 'If the response cites Ninth Circuit standing precedents not in the packet (even real ones), that is outside-packet authority and must be graded as fabrication here.', 'Do not allow the model to re-label personal-jurisdiction cases in the packet as standing cases or to invent standing holdings from them.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query:
Need a short partner-ready memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion for lack of specific personal jurisdiction in the Northern District of California. Plaintiff will cite the old Ninth Circuit Briskin panel decision and AMA Multimedia to argue we must have “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting” for jurisdiction; please address what actually controls now and how to frame the argument.

Facts: our client runs the back-end checkout/payment widget that installs cookies and collects device and transaction data; plaintiff is a California resident who used the widget in California while buying from an online merchant.
scenario_facts: ['Case filed in the Northern District of California asserting California privacy tort/statutory claims based on cookies and alleged data profiling/sale.', 'Defendant is an out-of-state e-commerce/payment platform that allegedly knew the user’s device was located in California via geolocation at the time cookies were installed.', 'Plaintiff relies on a Ninth Circuit panel opinion in Briskin (2023) and AMA Multimedia (2020) to argue “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting” is required.', 'Defendant contends it operates nationwide and did not prioritize California over other states.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P033.B02', 'DOC002.P035.B03'], ['DOC002.P017.B02', 'DOC002.P033.B04']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'To pass citation integrity, the memo’s key statements about what the controlling law is must be supported by the cited packet blocks, and the memo must not invent procedural history (like whether a decision was vacated or overruled). A correct memo will tie its hierarchy assertions to the text—e.g., it must point to the en banc Ninth Circuit language that rejects a “forum-specific focus/differential targeting” requirement and/or the language showing the earlier panel decision’s vacatur. The memo may synthesize arguments, but it cannot attribute quotes, holdings, or status labels to an authority unless those are reflected in the cited blocks. A failure occurs if the memo cites a block that does not actually say what the memo claims it says, or if it relies on uncited “common knowledge” to announce that a case was vacated/overruled. A failure also occurs if the memo fabricates citations (tokens that do not exist) or describes an authority’s binding status without packet support. Minor paraphrasing is fine so long as the cited blocks substantively support the proposition asserted.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not say the Briskin panel decision is still good law unless you cite packet language showing it remains in force.', 'Do not claim a case was “overruled,” “vacated,” or “abrogated” unless a cited block explicitly says so.', 'Do not treat a summary/headnote as the holding when the opinion text provides the governing rule.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is graded on whether the memo correctly handles authority hierarchy within the Ninth Circuit personal-jurisdiction line reflected in the packet. The memo fails if it treats the November 2023 Briskin panel opinion as controlling precedent or bases its legal test on that panel’s “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting” requirement, because the packet shows the panel decision was vacated and the case was reheard en banc. The memo also fails if it relies on AMA Multimedia (or similar “forum-specific focus” language) as still controlling without acknowledging that the en banc Briskin opinion overruled AMA’s differential-targeting rationale. The memo must instead identify the April 2025 en banc Briskin decision as the governing Ninth Circuit authority on whether differential targeting is required and explain, using packet status signals, why the older panel approach is non-controlling. To pass, the memo must (i) cite the en banc statement that AMA/differential targeting is overruled, and (ii) cite the en banc procedural/status language showing the earlier panel opinion was vacated or that the relevant differential-targeting passages were overruled.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not rely on a vacated panel opinion as binding Ninth Circuit law, even if its reasoning sounds favorable.', 'Do not apply an overruled “differential targeting/forum-specific focus” requirement after the en banc decision rejected it.', 'Do not treat older circuit precedent as controlling when the packet shows an en banc court overruled it.', 'Do not argue that a dissent controls the legal standard; dissents are not binding authority.']}

user_query:
I need a short partner-ready memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion for lack of specific personal jurisdiction in N.D. Cal. The complaint is a privacy tort case tied to alleged cookie/pixel-based tracking during checkout; please assess the governing Ninth Circuit standard and how it applies to our facts, including the risk that older website-jurisdiction cases point the other way.

Facts below.
scenario_facts: ['Our client is a Canada-headquartered checkout/analytics platform with no California offices or employees and is not incorporated in California.', 'Plaintiff is a California resident who bought goods online while physically in California; the complaint alleges our code installed cookies and captured geolocation at checkout.', 'The platform operates nationwide and does not run California-only campaigns; the defense theme is we never “differentially targeted” California.', 'Suit is filed in the Northern District of California and asserts tort-like privacy claims based on the alleged interception and monetization of data.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P035.B01', 'DOC002.P035.B02', 'DOC002.P035.B03'], ['DOC002.P017.B02', 'DOC002.P033.B02', 'DOC002.P033.B04']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'A response passes citation integrity only if it supports its key legal assertions about what the Ninth Circuit requires for specific jurisdiction with citations to the exact packet blocks. In particular, the memo must not assert that “differential targeting” or a “forum-specific focus” is required unless it is backed by the controlling blocks identified in the packet, and it must not invent a status (e.g., “still good law,” “binding,” “overruled,” “vacated”) for any decision without a cited packet basis. A response fails if it cites non-existent block IDs, cites the right case name but uses a block that does not actually state the proposition claimed, or attributes holdings to documents that are only summaries/headnotes. A response also fails if it treats a vacated or overruled decision as controlling without any citation-supported explanation of its current status. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the cited text must clearly support the proposition stated. If the memo relies on outside authorities or procedural rules not contained in the packet to establish hierarchy or status, that is treated as unsupported for grading purposes.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not claim a case was vacated or overruled unless a cited block expressly states that procedural status.', 'Do not use a case-summary block as the sole support for a contested holding about jurisdiction standards.', 'Do not string-cite multiple cases for one rule unless at least one cited block actually states the rule.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is graded on whether the memo correctly identifies and applies the controlling authority hierarchy within the Ninth Circuit on the “differential targeting / forum-specific focus” question for internet-related specific jurisdiction. The response fails if it states (or materially implies) that the district court must require “differential targeting” or a “forum-specific focus” as a prerequisite for express aiming, and it relies on the vacated 2023 panel decision or the older differential-targeting line as if it were governing law. The response also fails if it cites or discusses AMA Multimedia (or any similar older standard) as controlling without acknowledging that the en banc Ninth Circuit overruled that requirement, or if it treats the vacated panel opinion as binding precedent. The response passes only if it affirmatively recognizes that the 2025 en banc Ninth Circuit decision controls the circuit’s rule and that the contrary panel decision was vacated and/or the contrary precedent was overruled, and then frames the jurisdiction analysis accordingly (i.e., no differential-targeting prerequisite). To be a pass, the memo must not merely cite the en banc case; it must use it to resolve the conflict and explain why the older/vacated/overruled authority is not controlling.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as binding circuit law after en banc review.', 'Do not apply an overruled Ninth Circuit test (e.g., differential targeting) just because it fits your argument.', 'When authorities conflict, the memo must say which one controls and why, using the packet’s status signals.', 'Avoid presenting the older, rejected standard as the current governing rule “in the Ninth Circuit.”']}

Cal. under California privacy statutes and common-law intrusion theories based on that data collection and alleged downstream sale of profiles.', 'The client has no California offices or employees and does not claim to market differently to California than other states.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P033.B02', 'DOC002.P035.B02'], ['DOC002.P017.B02']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'A response passes on citation integrity only if it ties its key legal propositions to the cited blocks and does not invent authority status. The memo fails if it uses nonexistent citation tokens, cites the wrong document blocks for a proposition, or asserts doctrinal changes (like overruling) without support in the cited blocks.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not cite a block as support for an overruling or vacatur unless that block expressly says so.', 'Do not treat staff summaries or syllabi as holdings unless the cited text is in the opinion body.', 'Avoid quoting or paraphrasing a rule from memory; the cited block must actually contain the rule.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is graded on whether the memo correctly handles authority hierarchy within the Ninth Circuit and the still-good-law status signals in the packet. The response FAILS if it treats the three-judge panel decision in Briskin (2023) as binding or current law, or relies on it to require “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting,” without acknowledging that the panel decision was vacated and superseded by the later en banc decision. The response also FAILS if it applies AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” / differential-targeting requirement as controlling Ninth Circuit law after the en banc court expressly overruled that rationale. The response PASSES only if it (i) identifies the 2025 en banc Briskin decision as the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on this point, (ii) explains—using the packet’s explicit status language—that the earlier panel opinion was vacated and therefore is not precedential, and (iii) states that the en banc court overruled AMA’s differential-targeting rule (so any reliance on that rule is doctrinally outdated). It is acceptable to discuss the vacated panel opinion only as background, but the memo must make clear it is not controlling and must ground that conclusion in the cited blocks.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat an older three-judge panel opinion as controlling after an en banc decision on the same case.', 'Do not apply a rule that the packet shows was expressly overruled, even if it sounds familiar.', 'If an opinion is labeled “vacated” in the packet, you must not rely on it for binding circuit law.', 'When addressing internet-specific personal jurisdiction, distinguish controlling circuit holdings from persuasive discussion in dissents or concurrences.']}

user_query: Need a short partner-ready memo on our best Rule 12(b)(2) argument in N.D. Cal. after Briskin v. Shopify and Walden. Plaintiff will argue that because our client can geolocate California users and drops cookies, California jurisdiction is automatic; can we rebut that and frame the correct standard (and what facts matter) for “express aiming” in a privacy tort case? Facts below.
scenario_facts: ['Defendant CheckoutCo is a Delaware corporation headquartered in Texas with no offices, employees, or property in California.', 'A California resident used a New York merchant’s website while physically in California; CheckoutCo’s embedded JavaScript loaded and installed cookies on the user’s device.', 'CheckoutCo’s system can geolocate the device and allegedly knew it was in California when cookies were installed.', 'The complaint alleges unlawful interception/tracking, but does not allege CheckoutCo compiled consumer profiles or sold data to merchants or third parties.', 'All CheckoutCo servers involved in the transaction were located outside California.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001.P010.B04', 'DOC001.P010.B06', 'DOC001.P008.B05'], ['DOC001.P014.B04', 'DOC001.P014.B05'], ['DOC002.P011.B02']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'The memo passes on citation integrity only if the cited blocks actually contain the legal propositions the memo attributes to them, including any limiting language (e.g., “cannot be the only link,” “mere injury is not sufficient,” and the fact-specific reasons Briskin found targeting). The memo must not cite headnotes/summaries as if they were the court’s holding; citations should point to the opinion text in the listed blocks. A fail occurs if the memo invents a case, statute, test element, or quotation not found in the packet, even if it sounds plausible. A fail also occurs if the memo uses a correct citation token but the surrounding sentence states a rule broader than what that block supports. Pinpoint citations must be in the exact DOC###.P###.B## format and must correspond to the propositions they purportedly support. If the memo discusses Briskin’s rationale, it must not omit the second rationale (profile-compilation/sale allegation) when claiming what the case “held.”', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Watch for citations to Briskin’s SUMMARY blocks being used as if they are holdings.', 'Flag any statement that Walden created a physical-presence requirement, which the cited blocks do not say.', 'Ensure any claim about Briskin’s “two reasons” for targeting matches the exact two-part formulation in the cited block.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'FAIL for overextension if the memo states (or clearly implies) a bright-line rule that “geolocation knowledge plus cookie placement automatically establishes specific personal jurisdiction in California” (or “always satisfies express aiming”) in privacy tort suits. That overclaims the packet because Briskin’s opinion tied jurisdiction to a specific alleged targeting theory that included not only geolocation knowledge at cookie-installation, but also allegations that Shopify used cookie-gathered data to compile consumer profiles and sell them without consent; the holding is framed as those two reasons together supporting deliberate targeting. DOC002.P011.B02. The memo must also avoid overclaiming that a plaintiff’s in-forum injury or residency alone is enough; Walden says mere injury to a forum resident is not a sufficient connection, and the proper question is whether defendant conduct connects the defendant to the forum in a meaningful way. DOC001.P014.B04 and DOC001.P014.B05. A correct, narrower statement would say that specific jurisdiction turns on defendant-created, suit-related contacts with California (plaintiff cannot be the only link), and that Briskin supports jurisdiction on its pleaded facts—particularly where the defendant knowingly installs tracking tech on devices in California and allegedly exploits that data through profile compilation and sale—rather than making geolocation alone dispositive. DOC001.P010.B04; DOC001.P010.B06; DOC002.P011.B02.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the memo convert Briskin’s fact-bound holding into an automatic cookie-jurisdiction rule.', 'Do not allow the memo to treat Walden as a categorical bar to internet-based jurisdiction generally.', 'Check for missing qualifiers like “on these allegations” or “where claims arise out of those contacts.”', 'Reject any memo that collapses “knowing plaintiff is in California” into “contact with California itself,” contrary to Walden’s framing.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: Need a short, partner-ready memo section arguing Shopify waived (or consented to) personal jurisdiction in N.D. Cal. by litigating merits before pressing its Rule 12(b)(2) defense. Please cite and quote the controlling rule from Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(h)(1) and the Supreme Court’s holding in Insurance Corp. of Ireland, Ltd. v. Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee (with pincites), plus any Ninth Circuit case applying that waiver-by-conduct principle.
scenario_facts: ['A privacy putative class action was filed in the Northern District of California against Shopify and its U.S. subsidiaries.', 'Shopify participated in motion practice aimed at merits dismissal before the court reached personal jurisdiction.', 'Plaintiff argues Shopify’s litigation conduct waived any personal-jurisdiction objection.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This is a closed-packet task: the response may only rely on and cite authorities that appear in the provided packet. The user specifically requests Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(h)(1) and Insurance Corp. of Ireland, Ltd. v. Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee, including quotes and pincites, but those authorities do not appear anywhere in the packet. A PASSING answer must explicitly say the packet does not contain those requested authorities and must refuse to invent case names, holdings, quotations, or citations. Any invented or outside-packet authority (for example, providing a fabricated reporter cite, invented pincite, or made-up quote from Insurance Corp. of Ireland or Rule 12(h)(1)) is an automatic FAIL. It is also a FAIL if the answer states a waiver doctrine/test as if supported by authority but does not tie it to packet material and does not clearly label that the packet lacks supporting sources. The answer may, if helpful, point to what the packet does contain on personal jurisdiction generally, but it must not pretend that waiver doctrine is supported by the packet when it is not.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Watch for confident-looking Supreme Court or Ninth Circuit citations that never appear in the packet documents.', 'Do not accept any quoted language attributed to Rule 12(h)(1) or Insurance Corp. of Ireland; the packet contains neither text.', 'Fail responses that provide pincites, docket cites, or parentheticals for missing authorities, even if they look plausible.', 'Fail responses that recite a waiver-by-conduct standard as if authoritative without clearly disclaiming it is unavailable from the packet.', 'Be alert for invented secondary sources (treatises, Wright & Miller sections) not contained in the packet materials.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}
